title: 104_hr1272
content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section allowing deductions for postsecondary education expenses. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to deduct qualified postsecondary education expenses paid during the taxable year. There are dollar limitations of $10,000 per student and $20,000 per taxpayer for these deductions. Qualified postsecondary education expenses include tuition and related expenses. Qualified tuition and related expenses for attendance at an eligible educational institution include tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and reasonable living expenses while away from home. These expenses can be deducted from taxable income, subject to dollar limitations. The term 'eligible educational institution' is defined in section 135(c)(3). No double benefit is allowed for qualified postsecondary education expenses under subsection (a) if a deduction is allowed under any other provision of this chapter. A deduction for qualified postsecondary education expenses is only allowed if the expenses exceed the amount excludable under section 135 for the taxable year. Special rules apply. Special rules apply to reduce qualified postsecondary education expenses by certain scholarships and veterans benefits received during the period. Amounts paid for these expenses must exceed the excludable amount under section 135 for the taxable year. The deduction for postsecondary education expenses is limited to courses that count towards a degree or certificate. The individual must be at least a half-time student at an eligible institution. No deduction is allowed for expenses if the individual is a dependent of another taxpayer. No deduction allowed for education expenses if taxpayer is a dependent of another person or for spouse unless taxpayer is entitled to exemption or files a joint return. The deduction for postsecondary education expenses is allowed in computing adjusted gross income under section 62(a) of the tax code. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections by striking the item relating to section 220. The deduction for postsecondary education expenses is allowed in computing adjusted gross income under section 62(a) of the tax code, with amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994.
